results.title: The Man who digs for fish
results.creator_credit: Jack Long, John Taylor and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Frank Jenkinson, eighty-two, has been digging for fish for twenty-five years. His unorthodox conservationist practices have increased the numbers of the salmon population in the Jarvis Inlet from a modest 500 to 25000. Using a spade and accompanied by his dog, Frank wades up and down the stream, digging for the newly hatched salmon that lie buried in the gravel. Without his intervention they risk dying before reaching maturity.

results.title: The Man who can't stop
results.creator_credit: Michael Rubbo, Richard Mason, Tom Daly, Film Australia and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Tells of the efforts of Francis Sutton to save the Australian coastline from pollution. Dedicated to this task Sutton works ceaselessly on maps, diagrams and plans in an attempt to find an alternative to the disposal of sewage through ocean outfalls. Though receiving many rebuffs, gradually he is gaining support, from a scientist, politician and from the people who live around him. Cinematography by Don McAlpine.

results.title: The Man that gravity forgot
results.creator_credit: Wijnand Nieuwenkam, Auricom Van Gelber and Coronet
results.brief_description: An animated film about the life of Bram, the only person in the world who is not affected by the force of gravity. As Bram narrates this account of his gravity-free life he presents basic scientific information about gravity, and reveals the important role that this force plays in our lives.

results.title: The Man in the mirror
results.creator_credit: Amram Nowak Associates and BNA Communications
results.brief_description: Using “Bert” a typical surburban dad/husband/managing executive, to show the mid-life crisis in home and especially at work. “Phil” a young executive has new innovative plans for the company but Bert is too threatened to pass on Phil’s ideas. Phil resigns and Bert gets questioned about it by his superior. The film is based on books written by Joe Batten.

results.title: The Man in the middle
results.creator_credit: Fred Moore, British Productivity Council and Millbank Films
results.brief_description: The supervisor is sandwiched in the no-man’s land between “them and us”. Intended for training supervisors, the film illustrates that they are required to maintain full production and look after the health, safety and welfare of the employees.

results.title: The Man in the blue helmet
results.creator_credit: Frank Jacoby, Alistair Cooke and United Nations Films
results.brief_description: Tells of current events in the United Nations and the work of the UN police force. The story of the United Nations soldier, how he came into being, how he works and lives in stange lands, often far from his own country. The problem of maintaining the peace in the Congo and in the Middle East is shown.

results.title: The Man in the blue and white Holden
results.creator_credit: Peter Luby, Jane Karslake and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: A comedy with suspense about childhood fears set in the late sixties. Following the disappearance of the Beaumont children, Colin is warned about a malevolent stranger who has abducted children. Colin believes he is being shadowed by the man in a blue and white Holden. The film recalls the childhood fears drummed into children by teachers and parents, of strangers in cars. Cast includes Jeffrey Walker, Fiona Corke and Chris McLean.

results.title: The Man and the giant: an Eskimo legend
results.creator_credit: Co Hoedeman, Pierre Moretti, Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This film is based on an Inuit legend and performed by the Inuit people themselves. There is no dialogue, but the action is punctuated by ‘katadjak’, or throatsinging, a traditional form of singing once widely practised by the Inuit but now mostly confined to the Eastern Arctic. Camera by Andre Dupont, editing by J. Richard Robesco, Eskimo sound effects by Aikimie Novalinga and soapstone carvings by Paulosie Sivuak.

results.title: The Mallee Fowl
results.creator_credit: David Moore and Peter Du Cane
results.brief_description: Mallee Fowl are the most remarkable of the world’s mound-building birds. The male bird builds a huge conical mound like a compost heap, which acts as an incubator for hatching the eggs. This fascinating documentary looks at the life-style of this unusual bird.
